docs.lead_paragraph: Chandra Sarene Ahamed, a daughter of Ann Ahamed and Dr. Sultan Ahamed of Mystic, Conn., was married yesterday to Juan C. Grisanty, a son of Celeste Reyes and Carlos Grisanty, both of Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic. The Rev. Grzegorz P. Brozonowicz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Mother of the Redeemer Church in Groton, Conn.

docs.lead_paragraph: In its uniquely intimate look at a long-term couples-therapy group, Laurie Abraham’s article (Aug. 12) demonstrates that truly committing to a process of finding out (with an excellent therapist) what will make a marriage better, and sticking with it, no matter how long it takes, could at the very least improve relationships and, in many cases, save marriages. How unfortunate that this form of therapy is largely available only to upper-income couples. Most marriage counseling is not covered by insurance, despite the fact that troubled marriages may lead to depression, anxiety and substance abuse, which can result in lost productivity and high additional health-care costs, to say nothing of divorce and its impact on children. The current in-vogue therapy, largely dictated by what insurance companies will and will not cover, is short-term cognitive behavioral therapy. This would not have repaired the 22-year marriage of Clem and Marie, nor is it likely to have much impact on long-ingrained dysfunctional patterns of behavior and communication in marriages that usually stem from each spouse’s unresolved family-of-origin issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the cost of natural disasters far beyond the insurance industry’s ability to pay, a new market has sprung up to spread the risk. But how do you calculate the odds of catastrophe?

headline.seo: New Orleans - Hurricane Katrina - Housing - Insurance - Natural Disasters and Storms - Real Estate

docs.snippet: With the cost of natural disasters far beyond the insurance industry’s ability to pay, a new market has sprung up to spread the risk. But how do you calculate the odds of catastrophe?

docs.lead_paragraph: It was Aug. 24, 2005, and New Orleans was still charming. Tropical Depression 12 was spinning from the Bahamas toward Florida, but the chances of an American city's being destroyed by nature were remote, even for one below sea level. An entire industry of weather bookies -- scientists who calculate the likelihood of various natural disasters -- had in effect set the odds: a storm that destroys $70 billion of insured property should strike the United States only once every 100 years. New Orleanians had made an art form of ignoring threats far more likely than this; indeed, their carelessness was a big reason they were supposedly more charming than other Americans. And it was true: New Orleanians found pleasure even in oblivion. But in their blindness to certain threats, they could not have been more typically American. From Miami to San Francisco, the nation's priciest real estate now faced beaches and straddled fault lines; its most vibrant cities occupied its most hazardous land. If, after World War II, you had set out to redistribute wealth to maximize the sums that might be lost to nature, you couldn't have done much better than Americans had done. And virtually no one -- not even the weather bookies -- fully understood the true odds.
docs.abstract: Michael Lewis article on new market in catastrophe bonds that has sprung up to spread financial risk of hurricanes and earthquakes, whose costs have risen far beyond insurance industry's ability to pay, and how hedge fund manager John Seo arrived at way to make covering that risk an attractive investment; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, who has said that his positions on some issues have "evolved" or changed in recent years, is set to discuss the details of a his health care plan in Florida today, which also seems to be something of an evolution from proposals he has supported in the past.
docs.abstract: The health care plan that Mitt Romney plans to unveil today differs significantly from the proposal he supported as governor of Massachusetts.
docs.snippet: The health care plan that Mitt Romney plans to unveil today differs significantly from the proposal he supported as governor of Massachusetts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney, an architect of Massachusetts’ universal health coverage plan, is unveiling his proposal for overhauling the nation’s health care system.
